content.value_statement: Writing concurrent Python code requires understanding specific patterns and avoiding common pitfalls. This skill provides production-ready asyncio patterns for building high-performance applications with proper error handling, graceful shutdown, and optimized resource management.
actual_capabilities: Show concurrent patterns using asyncio.gather, TaskGroup, and semaphores
Implement bounded concurrency to prevent resource exhaustion
Create production-ready HTTP clients and servers with aiohttp
Handle errors with retry patterns, circuit breakers, and fallbacks
Bridge synchronous and async code using run_in_executor
Debug async code with profiling, task introspection, and slow callback detection
limitations: Python 3.10+ required; some patterns need Python 3.11+
Does not provide runtime execution or code generation
Does not include database driver patterns (see python-database-patterns)
Requires understanding of basic async concepts

best_practices: Always use async libraries (aiohttp, aiosqlite) instead of blocking sync libraries
Keep references to created tasks to prevent garbage collection
Configure timeouts and connection pools for all external service calls
anti_patterns: Using time.sleep() instead of asyncio.sleep() blocks the entire event loop
Creating new aiohttp.ClientSession per request wastes resources
Using blocking I/O (open, requests) directly in async functions stalls concurrency

faq.question: What Python version do I need?
faq.answer: Python 3.10+ recommended. TaskGroup, asyncio.timeout, and ExceptionGroup require Python 3.11+.

faq.question: How many concurrent requests can I make?
faq.answer: Limit depends on target service rate limits. Use Semaphore for control; start with 10 concurrent and adjust.

faq.question: Can I mix sync and async code?
faq.answer: Yes, use run_in_executor for blocking operations. Never block the event loop with time.sleep or sync I/O.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This skill contains only pattern documentation. No code execution, file access, or network calls occur.

faq.question: Why is my async code slow?
faq.answer: Common causes: blocking calls, too few concurrent tasks, missing connection pooling, or slow external services.

faq.question: How is this different from threading?
faq.answer: Async uses cooperative multitasking with one thread, avoiding GIL limits. Better for I/O-bound workloads with many connections.
